channel.title: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file
channel.description:
How well does Jar2exe actually protect a JAR file from modification?
Say you make your JAR, obfuscate it, and then add make it an exe with Jar2exe, how easily could you get the code and/or modify it?
What Jar2exe offers: [code]Encrypted java program will not generate temporary files when runs: Comparing with other encrypt tools, the encrypted java program by this software will not generate temporary files when runs. So, the protected java program could not be gotten by monitoring disk I/O.[/code]
[code]Generated exe files can encrypt and protect java programs, no temporary files will be generated when program runs. [/code]
The site: http://www.regexlab.com/en/jar2exe/

item.title: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:20, topic:445418”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=548185.msg4020880#msg4020880 date=1340002309]

[quote author=t4 link=topic=548185.msg4020311#msg4020311 date=1339973582]

[quote author=s1gma link=topic=548185.msg4020279#msg4020279 date=1339971466]

http://gcc.gnu.org/java/

That actually takes the java source code or class files containing bytecode, converts it assembly and assembles it to object code just like gcc does with C source code. You can compile most of the standard library but nothing graphical. It does exist and it is there, but it really does defeat the purpose of java.

It would actually be more difficult to reverse engineer as you’d have to disassemble the executable and sift through a lot of assembly and you might get an increase in performance, but that depends on a lot of things.

This Jar2Exe thing looks fucking retarded to say the least.
“4.Generated exe files provide system tray icon support.”
HURRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR

if the compiler links the correct libraries to the executable (ie, the OS the application is being compiled for), what’s wrong with that? You’d still be able to write standard Java code…
[/quote]he was referring to the ‘write once, run anywhere’ principle

ah… well write once, compile a few times isn’t such a bad thing.
[/quote]case study: xchat (yes sometimes it really is a bad thing)

X-Chat is written in C, though… You’d have to go through a lot more hoops than what gcj provides.
[/quote]the attitude of ‘write once, compile a few times’ is applicable to C, C++ etc. too, and whilst libraries can be portable across platforms it doesn’t mean they’re necessarily easy to set up/use on other platforms. i thought you were simply referring to the model in general, not specifically to gcj with which it is indeed easy to avoid until you perhaps have to go looking for a way of making a gui with it, or other tasks which gcj’s library doesn’t provide (which then means probably interfacing with native libraries and facing the problems that can come with that)

i was talking about specifically gcj in relation to the concept.[/quote]ok, but we’re still stuck with the problem of gcj’s library’s limitations and how one might have to resort to ‘portable’ native libraries in certain scenarios. despite this, GCJ seems kinda dead anyway (excelsior jet really is a better alternative)

Read full topic
item.source: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file

item.source: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file

item.title: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

The jar can be unpacked because it’s appended to the file, so opening the executable as a ZIP file works because there’s a valid footer.
Here, I decompiled the classes using jad:

[code]// Decompiled by Jad v1.5.8g. Copyright 2001 Pavel Kouznetsov.
// Jad home page: http://www.kpdus.com/jad.html
// Decompiler options: packimports(3) noctor nonlb space
// Source File Name: Hello.java

package test;

import java.io.PrintStream;

public class Hello {

public static void main(String args[]) {
    System.out.println("Hello, world");
}

}[/code]

[code]// Decompiled by Jad v1.5.8g. Copyright 2001 Pavel Kouznetsov.
// Jad home page: http://www.kpdus.com/jad.html
// Decompiler options: packimports(3) noctor nonlb space
// Source File Name: HelloWorld.java

package test;

import java.awt.*;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JTextField;

public class HelloWorld extends JFrame {

public HelloWorld() {
    JTextField jtextfield = new JTextField("Hello, world");
    getContentPane().add(jtextfield);
}

public static void main(String args[]) {
    HelloWorld helloworld = new HelloWorld();
    Toolkit toolkit = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit();
    int i = toolkit.getScreenSize().width;
    int j = toolkit.getScreenSize().height;
    helloworld.setSize(100, 100);
    helloworld.setLocation((i - 100) / 2, (j - 100) / 2);
    helloworld.setVisible(true);
    helloworld.setDefaultCloseOperation(3);
}

}[/code]

Jar2Exe using the “hide” mechanism instead places the archive in a type 10 RCDATA resource, which is somehow processed prior to being fed through the ZipArchive library for unpacking.
The encryption option merely adds an additional layer to this hide mechanism by employing a homebrew stream cipher named XOR256 to the data. XOR256 used to be documented here, but as you can see the page is suspended, likely because the code went proprietary. You can find it here, however:
https://scenarioframework.svn.codeplex.com/svn/src/Scenario%20Libraries/cppbOSCrypto/Crypto/bOSXOR256Stream.h
https://scenarioframework.svn.codeplex.com/svn/src/Scenario%20Libraries/cppbOSCrypto/Crypto/bOSXOR256Stream.cpp

That all being said, all of these techniques can be readily defeated using a JVM debugging agent.

Read full topic
item.source: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file

item.title: [Java] Jar2exe to protect a JAR file
item.dc:creator: @walkineagle walkineagle
item.description:
@walkineagle wrote:

No they don’t… not jar2exe, that’s the point.

Jar2exe encrypts and hides the JAR and only produces C files. I want to know how vulnerable it is.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

[quote=“walkineagle, post:6, topic:445418”]What?

Did you use Jar2exe on that?[/quote]
No, this is a client of a rsps that is ‘converted’ to .exe.
But maybe other exe converters don’t do that.

item.description:
@walkineagle wrote:

@Native
It doesn’t quite work like that, it’s not just a JAR file placed in an EXE file.
There are no Java files in the EXE. Just C files.

@veer
http://www.regexlab.com/jar2exe/test.zip
I believe that will suffice? It’s an example of a windows GUI application. It comes with the regular JAR, an exe, a console exe, and the class files.
